Audience Member 1: "We know that your administration would follow the science."\n
Audience Member 1: "My question for you, it’s two parts."\n
Audience Member 1: "First, looking backwards to when this country first became aware of COVID-19, what would following the science have meant in terms of actual policy?"\n
Audience Member 1: "And then, looking forward, what would your administration do in terms of following the science with real concrete policies that haven’t been done by the current administration?"\n
Joe Biden: "Well, first of all, going back, the fact is that the president was informed how dangerous this virus was."\n
Joe Biden: "And all the way back in the beginning of February, I argued that we should be keeping people in China."\n
Joe Biden: "And we had set up, in our administration, a pandemic office within the White House."\n
Joe Biden: "There were 44 people on the ground."\n
Joe Biden: "I suggested that we should be seeking, and I didn’t hold public office, I was a former Vice President, we in fact asked to have access to the source of the problem."\n
Joe Biden: "And the best of our knowledge, Trump never pushed that."\n
 n040016b07p1218 50000 5 not_argumentative neither 70000 5 not_argumentative neither 80000 5 not_argumentative neither
Audience Member 1: "Thank you, George."\n
Audience Member 1: "Mr. Vice President, every day, my wife and I are in disbelief at the lack of coordinated federal action on COVID-19."\n
Audience Member 1: "We know that your administration would follow the science."\n
Audience Member 1: "My question for you, it’s two parts."\n
Audience Member 1: "First, looking backwards to when this country first became aware of COVID-19, what would following the science have meant in terms of actual policy?"\n
Audience Member 1: "And then, looking forward, what would your administration do in terms of following the science with real concrete policies that haven’t been done by the current administration?"\n
Joe Biden: "Well, first of all, going back, the fact is that the president was informed how dangerous this virus was."\n
Joe Biden: "And all the way back in the beginning of February, I argued that we should be keeping people in China."\n
Joe Biden: "And we had set up, in our administration, a pandemic office within the White House."\n
Joe Biden: "There were 44 people on the ground."\n
Joe Biden: "I suggested that we should be seeking, and I didn’t hold public office, I was a former Vice President, we in fact asked to have access to the source of the problem."\n
Joe Biden: "And the best of our knowledge, Trump never pushed that."\n
Joe Biden: "All those 44 people came home, never got replaced."\n
Joe Biden: "In addition to that, I pointed out that I thought in February, I did a piece for USA Today saying, “This is a serious problem."\n
Joe Biden: "Trump denied it."\n

Audience Member 1: "We know that your administration would follow the science."\n
Audience Member 1: "My question for you, it’s two parts."\n
Audience Member 1: "First, looking backwards to when this country first became aware of COVID-19, what would following the science have meant in terms of actual policy?"\n
Audience Member 1: "And then, looking forward, what would your administration do in terms of following the science with real concrete policies that haven’t been done by the current administration?"\n
Joe Biden: "Well, first of all, going back, the fact is that the president was informed how dangerous this virus was."\n
Joe Biden: "And all the way back in the beginning of February, I argued that we should be keeping people in China."\n
Joe Biden: "And we had set up, in our administration, a pandemic office within the White House."\n
Joe Biden: "There were 44 people on the ground."\n
Joe Biden: "I suggested that we should be seeking, and I didn’t hold public office, I was a former Vice President, we in fact asked to have access to the source of the problem."\n
Joe Biden: "And the best of our knowledge, Trump never pushed that."\n
Joe Biden: "All those 44 people came home, never got replaced."\n
Joe Biden: "In addition to that, I pointed out that I thought in February, I did a piece for USA Today saying, “This is a serious problem."\n
Joe Biden: "Trump denied it."\n
Joe Biden: "He said it wasn’t.”"\n
Joe Biden: "We later learned that he knew full well how serious it was when he did an interview with George Woodward."\n

Audience Member 1: "My question for you, it’s two parts."\n
Audience Member 1: "First, looking backwards to when this country first became aware of COVID-19, what would following the science have meant in terms of actual policy?"\n
Audience Member 1: "And then, looking forward, what would your administration do in terms of following the science with real concrete policies that haven’t been done by the current administration?"\n
Joe Biden: "Well, first of all, going back, the fact is that the president was informed how dangerous this virus was."\n
Joe Biden: "And all the way back in the beginning of February, I argued that we should be keeping people in China."\n
Joe Biden: "And we had set up, in our administration, a pandemic office within the White House."\n
Joe Biden: "There were 44 people on the ground."\n
Joe Biden: "I suggested that we should be seeking, and I didn’t hold public office, I was a former Vice President, we in fact asked to have access to the source of the problem."\n
Joe Biden: "And the best of our knowledge, Trump never pushed that."\n
Joe Biden: "All those 44 people came home, never got replaced."\n
Joe Biden: "In addition to that, I pointed out that I thought in February, I did a piece for USA Today saying, “This is a serious problem."\n
Joe Biden: "Trump denied it."\n
Joe Biden: "He said it wasn’t.”"\n
Joe Biden: "We later learned that he knew full well how serious it was when he did an interview with George Woodward."\n
Joe Biden: "I mean, excuse me, Bob Woodward."\n

Audience Member 1: "And then, looking forward, what would your administration do in terms of following the science with real concrete policies that haven’t been done by the current administration?"\n
Joe Biden: "Well, first of all, going back, the fact is that the president was informed how dangerous this virus was."\n
Joe Biden: "And all the way back in the beginning of February, I argued that we should be keeping people in China."\n
Joe Biden: "And we had set up, in our administration, a pandemic office within the White House."\n
Joe Biden: "There were 44 people on the ground."\n
Joe Biden: "I suggested that we should be seeking, and I didn’t hold public office, I was a former Vice President, we in fact asked to have access to the source of the problem."\n
Joe Biden: "And the best of our knowledge, Trump never pushed that."\n
Joe Biden: "All those 44 people came home, never got replaced."\n
Joe Biden: "In addition to that, I pointed out that I thought in February, I did a piece for USA Today saying, “This is a serious problem."\n
Joe Biden: "Trump denied it."\n
Joe Biden: "He said it wasn’t.”"\n
Joe Biden: "We later learned that he knew full well how serious it was when he did an interview with George Woodward."\n
Joe Biden: "I mean, excuse me, Bob Woodward."\n
Joe Biden: "And at the time, he said he didn’t tell anybody because he was afraid Americans would panic."\n
Joe Biden: "Americans don’t panic, he panicked."\n
 n040024b07p2427 60000 3 not_related neither 40000 5 not_argumentative neither 80000 4 not_related neither
Joe Biden: "All those 44 people came home, never got replaced."\n
Joe Biden: "In addition to that, I pointed out that I thought in February, I did a piece for USA Today saying, “This is a serious problem."\n
Joe Biden: "Trump denied it."\n
Joe Biden: "He said it wasn’t.”"\n
Joe Biden: "We later learned that he knew full well how serious it was when he did an interview with George Woodward."\n
Joe Biden: "I mean, excuse me, Bob Woodward."\n
Joe Biden: "And at the time, he said he didn’t tell anybody because he was afraid Americans would panic."\n
Joe Biden: "Americans don’t panic, he panicked."\n
Joe Biden: "He didn’t say a word to anybody."\n
Joe Biden: "Then I wrote a piece in March about what I thought we should be doing to take hold of this, using the… There’s an act that passed a long time ago that allows the president to go into a business and say, “Stop making this, and start making that.” And it took a long time for him to even institute that, to get ventilators and so on."\n
Joe Biden: "And so, the point was he missed enormous opportunities and kept saying things that weren’t true."\n
Joe Biden: "It’s going to go away by Easter, don’t worry about it."\n
Joe Biden: "When the summer comes, it’s all going to go away like a miracle."\n
Joe Biden: "He’s still saying those things."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "Before you go to the future, can I follow up on the, “I’m looking backwards.” just a little bit?"\n

George Stephanopoulos: "In January, February."\n
Joe Biden: "Not in January, February."\n

Joe Biden: "That came at the end of March."\n
Joe Biden: "And then I laid out a detailed plan relative to school openings in June and July."\n
Joe Biden: "By that time, the science was becoming clearer and clearer of how this was spreading so rapidly."\n
Joe Biden: "But the president kept denying that."\n
Joe Biden: "If you notice, from March on, I stopped doing big meetings, I started wearing masks."\n

 n040043b07p4047 50000 5 showing attack argument attack 80000 4 not_related neither 60000 3 not_related neither
Joe Biden: "Not back then."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "In January, February."\n
Joe Biden: "Not in January, February."\n
Joe Biden: "No, that’s correct, there wasn’t."\n
Joe Biden: "That came at the end of March."\n
Joe Biden: "And then I laid out a detailed plan relative to school openings in June and July."\n
Joe Biden: "By that time, the science was becoming clearer and clearer of how this was spreading so rapidly."\n
Joe Biden: "But the president kept denying that."\n
Joe Biden: "If you notice, from March on, I stopped doing big meetings, I started wearing masks."\n
Joe Biden: "So, it was at a time when the science was saying, and his key people, Dr. Fauci were saying, “You should be taking these precautions.” So, what we should be doing now, there should be a national standard."\n
Joe Biden: "Instead of leaving this up to, remember what the president said to the governors, “Well, they’re on their own, it’s not my responsibility."\n
Joe Biden: "The governors can do what they need to do, not my responsibility.” It is a presidential responsibility to lead, and he didn’t do that."\n
Joe Biden: "He didn’t talk about what needed to be done because he kept worrying, in my view, about the stock market."\n
Joe Biden: "He worried if he talked about how bad this could be, unless we took these precautionary actions, then in fact, the market would go down."\n
Joe Biden: "And his barometer of success to the economy is the market."\n

 n040047b07p4548 40000 5 not_argumentative neither 50000 5 not_argumentative neither 60000 3 not_related neither
Joe Biden: "And then I laid out a detailed plan relative to school openings in June and July."\n
Joe Biden: "By that time, the science was becoming clearer and clearer of how this was spreading so rapidly."\n
Joe Biden: "But the president kept denying that."\n
Joe Biden: "If you notice, from March on, I stopped doing big meetings, I started wearing masks."\n
Joe Biden: "So, it was at a time when the science was saying, and his key people, Dr. Fauci were saying, “You should be taking these precautions.” So, what we should be doing now, there should be a national standard."\n
Joe Biden: "Instead of leaving this up to, remember what the president said to the governors, “Well, they’re on their own, it’s not my responsibility."\n
Joe Biden: "The governors can do what they need to do, not my responsibility.” It is a presidential responsibility to lead, and he didn’t do that."\n
Joe Biden: "He didn’t talk about what needed to be done because he kept worrying, in my view, about the stock market."\n
Joe Biden: "He worried if he talked about how bad this could be, unless we took these precautionary actions, then in fact, the market would go down."\n
Joe Biden: "And his barometer of success to the economy is the market."\n
Joe Biden: "Thirdly, what we didn’t do is, the president had an opportunity to open and allow schools and businesses to stay open if they got the kind of help they needed."\n
Joe Biden: "So, the Congress passed a couple of trillion dollars worth of help."\n
Joe Biden: "And what happened was most of that money, a significant portion of that money went to the very wealthiest corporations in the country, didn’t get to the mom and pop stores."\n
Joe Biden: "So, you had one in five, one in six minority businesses closing."\n
Joe Biden: "Many of them permanently."\n
 n040052b07p5153 40000 5 not_argumentative neither 50000 5 not_argumentative neither 80000 4 Biden's statement is about presidential responsibility support
Joe Biden: "He didn’t talk about what needed to be done because he kept worrying, in my view, about the stock market."\n
Joe Biden: "He worried if he talked about how bad this could be, unless we took these precautionary actions, then in fact, the market would go down."\n
Joe Biden: "And his barometer of success to the economy is the market."\n
Joe Biden: "Thirdly, what we didn’t do is, the president had an opportunity to open and allow schools and businesses to stay open if they got the kind of help they needed."\n
Joe Biden: "So, the Congress passed a couple of trillion dollars worth of help."\n
Joe Biden: "And what happened was most of that money, a significant portion of that money went to the very wealthiest corporations in the country, didn’t get to the mom and pop stores."\n
Joe Biden: "So, you had one in five, one in six minority businesses closing."\n
Joe Biden: "Many of them permanently."\n
Joe Biden: "People being laid off."\n
Joe Biden: "And then what happened was, when the first round of money for unemployment, enhanced unemployment went by, he didn’t do anything."\n
Joe Biden: "He didn’t do anything."\n
Joe Biden: "And to the best of my knowledge, and I mean this sincerely, I can’t think of, I’ve been around for a lot of presidents, and you know a lot of presidents in a crisis, I don’t ever remember one never calling the House and Senate Republicans, Democrats together."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "Let’s look forward a little bit."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "You said that you would lock down the economy, only if the scientists said it was necessary."\n
Joe Biden: "By the way, in the context, would I lock down the economy if science said so?"\n

Joe Biden: "For example, I laid out a plan, how you can open businesses."\n
Joe Biden: "You can open businesses and schools, if in fact you provide them the guidance that they need, as well as the money to be able to do it."\n

Joe Biden: "They don’t continue until they figure out what the problem was."\n
Joe Biden: "They’re not there yet."\n

Joe Biden: "And in the meantime, what I worry about is the same thing with Regeneron, which is a useful antidote."\n
Joe Biden: "Not antidote, a useful tool."\n

Joe Biden: "Well, we don’t have all the testing equipment."\n
Joe Biden: "We don’t have all the ability to get it to the people who need it."\n
Joe Biden: "And what we should be doing now, and allegedly it’s happening, but I’ve not seen it yet nor the docs that I’ve talked to seen it."\n
Joe Biden: "There should be a plan when we have the vaccine, how do we distribute it?"\n
George Stephanopoulos: "And once we get it, if it’s safe, if it’s effective, will you mandate its use?"\n

Joe Biden: "And the most scientists say, that it’s not likely to have a vaccine that would be available until the beginning of next year, into the spring of next year."\n
Joe Biden: "And in the meantime, what I worry about is the same thing with Regeneron, which is a useful antidote."\n
Joe Biden: "Not antidote, a useful tool."\n
Joe Biden: "But what’s happening is there was no plan to figure out how to distribute it."\n
Joe Biden: "We have 500,000 vials of it."\n
Joe Biden: "Well, we don’t have all the testing equipment."\n
Joe Biden: "We don’t have all the ability to get it to the people who need it."\n
Joe Biden: "And what we should be doing now, and allegedly it’s happening, but I’ve not seen it yet nor the docs that I’ve talked to seen it."\n
Joe Biden: "There should be a plan when we have the vaccine, how do we distribute it?"\n
George Stephanopoulos: "And once we get it, if it’s safe, if it’s effective, will you mandate its use?"\n
Joe Biden: "The answer is, depending on how clear… Vaccines, they say, have a very positive impact and that you’re going to affect positively 85% of the American public."\n
Joe Biden: "Or there’s others say, “This vaccine is really the key."\n
Joe Biden: "This is the golden key.” It depends on the state of the nature of the vaccine when it comes out, and how it’s being distributed."\n
Joe Biden: "But I would think that we should be talking about, depending on the continuation of the spread of the virus, we should be thinking about making it mandatory."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "How would you enforce that?"\n

Joe Biden: "Just like you can’t enforce measles, you can’t come to school unless you have a measles shot."\n

Joe Biden: "The answer is, depending on how clear… Vaccines, they say, have a very positive impact and that you’re going to affect positively 85% of the American public."\n
Joe Biden: "Or there’s others say, “This vaccine is really the key."\n
Joe Biden: "This is the golden key.” It depends on the state of the nature of the vaccine when it comes out, and how it’s being distributed."\n
Joe Biden: "But I would think that we should be talking about, depending on the continuation of the spread of the virus, we should be thinking about making it mandatory."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "How would you enforce that?"\n
Joe Biden: "Well, you couldn’t, that’s the problem."\n
Joe Biden: "Just like you can’t enforce measles, you can’t come to school unless you have a measles shot."\n
Joe Biden: "You know, you can’t."\n
Joe Biden: "But you can’t say, everyone has to do this, just like you can’t mandate a mask."\n
Joe Biden: "But you can say, you can go to every governor and get them all in a room, all 50 of them as president and say, ” Ask people to wear the mask."\n

George Stephanopoulos: "And if they don’t?"\n
George Stephanopoulos: "Fines?"\n
Joe Biden: "And if they don’t, no."\n
Joe Biden: "Not fine."\n
Joe Biden: "Then I go to every governor, I go to every mayor, I go to every councilmen, and I go to every local official, say, “Mandate the mask.” Say, “This is what you have to do when you’re out."\n
Joe Biden: "Make sure you encourage it being done.” Look, George, you and I know, and I think you do too as well, the words of a president matter."\n
Audience Member 2: "Absolutely."\n
Joe Biden: "No matter whether they’re good, bad, or indifferent, they matter."\n
Joe Biden: "And when a president doesn’t wear a mask or makes fun of folks like me, when I was wearing a mask for a long time, then people say, “Well, it mustn’t be that important.” But when a president says, “I think this is very important.” For example, I walked in here with this mask, but I have one of the N95 masks underneath it."\n
Joe Biden: "I left it in my dressing room."\n
Joe Biden: "Not the dresser, the room I was in before I got here."\n
Joe Biden: "And so, I think it matters what we say."\n
Joe Biden: "And we’re now learning that children are getting the virus, not with as serious consequences, but there’s been no studies done yet on vaccines for children."\n
Joe Biden: "So, there’s a long way to go, but we can make progress in the meantime and save lives."\n
 n040164b07p6571 60000 3 not_related neither 50000 5 not_related neither 90000 5 context collaborates the idea of saving people regardless of status. support
Joe Biden: "Then I go to every governor, I go to every mayor, I go to every councilmen, and I go to every local official, say, “Mandate the mask.” Say, “This is what you have to do when you’re out."\n
Joe Biden: "Make sure you encourage it being done.” Look, George, you and I know, and I think you do too as well, the words of a president matter."\n
Audience Member 2: "Absolutely."\n
Joe Biden: "No matter whether they’re good, bad, or indifferent, they matter."\n
Joe Biden: "And when a president doesn’t wear a mask or makes fun of folks like me, when I was wearing a mask for a long time, then people say, “Well, it mustn’t be that important.” But when a president says, “I think this is very important.” For example, I walked in here with this mask, but I have one of the N95 masks underneath it."\n
Joe Biden: "I left it in my dressing room."\n
Joe Biden: "Not the dresser, the room I was in before I got here."\n
Joe Biden: "And so, I think it matters what we say."\n
Joe Biden: "And we’re now learning that children are getting the virus, not with as serious consequences, but there’s been no studies done yet on vaccines for children."\n
Joe Biden: "So, there’s a long way to go, but we can make progress in the meantime and save lives."\n
Joe Biden: "And the last point I’ll make, if you listen to the head of the CDC, he stood up and he said, “You know, while we’re waiting for a vaccine.” He held up a mask."\n
Joe Biden: "“You wear this mask, you’ll save more lives between now and the end of the year than if we had a vaccine.” It’s estimated by every major study done from the University of Washington to Columbia, that if in fact we wore masks, we could save, between now and the end of the year, a hundred thousand lives."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "And avoid lock downs?"\n
Joe Biden: "And avoid lockdown, yes."\n
Joe Biden: "You don’t have to lock down if you’re wearing the mask."\n

Joe Biden: "And so, I think it matters what we say."\n
Joe Biden: "And we’re now learning that children are getting the virus, not with as serious consequences, but there’s been no studies done yet on vaccines for children."\n
Joe Biden: "So, there’s a long way to go, but we can make progress in the meantime and save lives."\n
Joe Biden: "And the last point I’ll make, if you listen to the head of the CDC, he stood up and he said, “You know, while we’re waiting for a vaccine.” He held up a mask."\n
Joe Biden: "“You wear this mask, you’ll save more lives between now and the end of the year than if we had a vaccine.” It’s estimated by every major study done from the University of Washington to Columbia, that if in fact we wore masks, we could save, between now and the end of the year, a hundred thousand lives."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "And avoid lock downs?"\n
Joe Biden: "And avoid lockdown, yes."\n
Joe Biden: "You don’t have to lock down if you’re wearing the mask."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "Let’s get a question on the economy."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "Anthony Archer-"\n
Joe Biden: "Thank you, I hope I answered your question."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "… from Canonsburg, Pennsylvania, it’s a suburb of Pittsburgh."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "Republican."\n
Joe Biden: "I know it."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "Voted for President Trump."\n
 n040176b07p7677 40000 5 not_argumentative neither 50000 5 not_argumentative neither 60000 3 none of the sentences are providing an argument support
Audience Member 3: "Thank you, Mr. Vice President."\n
Audience Member 3: "You stated that anyone making less than $400,000 will not see one single penny of their taxes raised."\n
Joe Biden: "That’s right."\n
Audience Member 3: "But also, state that you are going to eliminate the Trump tax cuts."\n
Audience Member 3: "The Trump tax cuts reduces taxes for the majority of workers."\n
Audience Member 3: "I would argue, not enough."\n
Audience Member 3: "What is your plan for either extending the tax cuts for the middle-class, or creating a new plan that further reduces those taxes?"\n
Joe Biden: "I carry this card with me."\n
Joe Biden: "When I said the Trump tax cuts, about 1.3 trillion of the $2 trillion in his tax cuts went to the top one 10th of 1%."\n
Joe Biden: "That’s what I’m talking about eliminating, not all the tax cuts that are out there."\n
Joe Biden: "And by the way, if you take a look, we reduced the corporate tax rate from 35%."\n
Joe Biden: "and Democrats, Republicans who were in office thought it should come down to 28%."\n
Joe Biden: "He reduced it to 21%."\n
Joe Biden: "You have 91 out of the Fortune 500 companies not paying a single solitary penny."\n
Joe Biden: "If you raise the corporate tax back to 28%, which is a fair tax, you’d raise one trillion, three hundred billion dollars by that one act."\n

Joe Biden: "When I said the Trump tax cuts, about 1.3 trillion of the $2 trillion in his tax cuts went to the top one 10th of 1%."\n
Joe Biden: "That’s what I’m talking about eliminating, not all the tax cuts that are out there."\n
Joe Biden: "And by the way, if you take a look, we reduced the corporate tax rate from 35%."\n
Joe Biden: "and Democrats, Republicans who were in office thought it should come down to 28%."\n
Joe Biden: "He reduced it to 21%."\n

Joe Biden: "And one helps the other."\n
Joe Biden: "For example, we’re going to invest a great deal of that money into infrastructure, and to a green infrastructure."\n
Joe Biden: "We’re going to put 500,000 charging stations on new highways we’re building, and all highways we’re building."\n

Joe Biden: "You know as well as I do from your days, you know, in the old days, where the president spends about $600 billion a year on government contracts."\n
Joe Biden: "Everything from making sure they have aircraft carriers, to automobile fleets in the United States."\n
Joe Biden: "If you make, and it’s not in violation of any international trade agreement, made in America."\n
Joe Biden: "If you actually insist that whatever that product is, made in America, including the material that goes into the product."\n
Joe Biden: "It is estimated we’re going to create somewhere between another four and six million jobs just by doing that."\n
Joe Biden: "But what’s happening now under his trade policy, a lot of this is going overseas."\n

Joe Biden: "Good evening."\n

Audience Member 4: "Many people believe that the true swing demographic in this election will be Black voters under the age of 30, not because they’ll be voting for Trump, but because they won’t vote at all."\n
Audience Member 4: "I myself have had this exact same conflict."\n
Audience Member 4: "So my question for you then is, besides “You ain’t Black,” what do you have to say to young Black voters who see voting for you as further participation in a system that continually fails to protect them?"\n
Joe Biden: "Well, I’d say first of all, as my buddy John Lewis said, “It’s a sacred opportunity, the right to vote."\n
Joe Biden: "You can make a difference.” If young Black women and men vote, you can determine the outcome of this election."\n
Joe Biden: "Not a joke."\n
Joe Biden: "You can do that."\n
Joe Biden: "Then the next question is, am I worthy of your vote?"\n
Joe Biden: "Can I earn your vote?"\n

Joe Biden: "One is, in addition to dealing with a criminal justice system to make it fairer and make it more decent, we have to be able to put Black Americans in a position to be able to gain wealth, generate wealth."\n
Joe Biden: "And so you look at what that entails."\n

Joe Biden: "We have one school psychologist in America now for every 1,507 kids."\n

Joe Biden: "And so that would allow them, for example, like we did in our administration, the President allowed me to go down and we awarded a cybersecurity laboratory, ability to compete for cybersecurity laboratory."\n

George Stephanopoulos: "Garnet Valley, Pennsylvania."\n
Audience Member 5: "Hi."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "Republican who voted for President Trump last time."\n
Joe Biden: "Thank you."\n
Audience Member 1: "Thank you, George."\n
Audience Member 5: "Thank you, Vice President Biden."\n
Audience Member 5: "Nice to meet you."\n
Audience Member 5: "What’s your view on the Crime Bill that you wrote 1994, which showed prejudice against minorities?"\n
Audience Member 5: "Where do you stand today on that?"\n
Joe Biden: "Well, first of all, things have changed drastically."\n
Joe Biden: "That Crime Bill, when it voted, the Black Caucus voted for it."\n
Joe Biden: "Every Black mayor supported it across the board and the Crime Bill itself did not have mandatory sentences except for two things."\n
Joe Biden: "It had three strikes and you’re out, which I voted against, in the Crime Bill, but it had a lot of other things in it that turned out to be both bad and good."\n
Joe Biden: "I wrote the Violence Against Women Act."\n
Joe Biden: "That was part of the assault weapons ban and other things that were good."\n
 n050095b07p9293 60000 3 not_argumentative neither 80000 5 not_argumentative neither 40000 5 not_argumentative neither
Audience Member 5: "What’s your view on the Crime Bill that you wrote 1994, which showed prejudice against minorities?"\n
Audience Member 5: "Where do you stand today on that?"\n
Joe Biden: "Well, first of all, things have changed drastically."\n
Joe Biden: "That Crime Bill, when it voted, the Black Caucus voted for it."\n
Joe Biden: "Every Black mayor supported it across the board and the Crime Bill itself did not have mandatory sentences except for two things."\n
Joe Biden: "It had three strikes and you’re out, which I voted against, in the Crime Bill, but it had a lot of other things in it that turned out to be both bad and good."\n
Joe Biden: "I wrote the Violence Against Women Act."\n
Joe Biden: "That was part of the assault weapons ban and other things that were good."\n
Joe Biden: "What I was against was giving states more money for prison systems that they could build, state prison systems."\n
Joe Biden: "And you have 93 out of every 100 people in jail now is in a state prison, not in a federal prison, because they built more prisons."\n
Joe Biden: "I also wrote into that bill a thing called drug courts."\n
Joe Biden: "I don’t believe anybody should be going to jail for drug use."\n
Joe Biden: "They should be going into mandatory rehabilitation."\n
Joe Biden: "We should be building rehab centers to have these people housed."\n
Joe Biden: "We should decriminalize marijuana, wipe out the record so you can actually say honesty, “You ever been arrested for murder for anything?” You can say no, because we’re going to pass a law saying there is no background that you have to reveal relative to the use of marijuana."\n

Joe Biden: "Every Black mayor supported it across the board and the Crime Bill itself did not have mandatory sentences except for two things."\n
Joe Biden: "It had three strikes and you’re out, which I voted against, in the Crime Bill, but it had a lot of other things in it that turned out to be both bad and good."\n
Joe Biden: "I wrote the Violence Against Women Act."\n
Joe Biden: "That was part of the assault weapons ban and other things that were good."\n
Joe Biden: "What I was against was giving states more money for prison systems that they could build, state prison systems."\n
Joe Biden: "And you have 93 out of every 100 people in jail now is in a state prison, not in a federal prison, because they built more prisons."\n
Joe Biden: "I also wrote into that bill a thing called drug courts."\n
Joe Biden: "I don’t believe anybody should be going to jail for drug use."\n
Joe Biden: "They should be going into mandatory rehabilitation."\n
Joe Biden: "We should be building rehab centers to have these people housed."\n
Joe Biden: "We should decriminalize marijuana, wipe out the record so you can actually say honesty, “You ever been arrested for murder for anything?” You can say no, because we’re going to pass a law saying there is no background that you have to reveal relative to the use of marijuana."\n
Joe Biden: "And so there’s a lot of things."\n
Joe Biden: "But in addition to that, we’ve got to change the system."\n
Joe Biden: "I joined with a group of people in the House to provide for changing the system from punishment to rehabilitation."\n
Joe Biden: "Along with a guy named Marlon Specter, who you may remember, I wrote the Second Chance Act."\n

Joe Biden: "And you have 93 out of every 100 people in jail now is in a state prison, not in a federal prison, because they built more prisons."\n
Joe Biden: "I also wrote into that bill a thing called drug courts."\n
Joe Biden: "I don’t believe anybody should be going to jail for drug use."\n
Joe Biden: "They should be going into mandatory rehabilitation."\n
Joe Biden: "We should be building rehab centers to have these people housed."\n
Joe Biden: "We should decriminalize marijuana, wipe out the record so you can actually say honesty, “You ever been arrested for murder for anything?” You can say no, because we’re going to pass a law saying there is no background that you have to reveal relative to the use of marijuana."\n
Joe Biden: "And so there’s a lot of things."\n
Joe Biden: "But in addition to that, we’ve got to change the system."\n

Joe Biden: "Along with a guy named Marlon Specter, who you may remember, I wrote the Second Chance Act."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "In the meantime, an awful lot of people were jailed for minor drug crimes after the Crime Bill."\n
Joe Biden: "Right."\n

Joe Biden: "What I was against was giving states more money for prison systems that they could build, state prison systems."\n
Joe Biden: "And you have 93 out of every 100 people in jail now is in a state prison, not in a federal prison, because they built more prisons."\n

Joe Biden: "They should be going into mandatory rehabilitation."\n

Joe Biden: "And so there’s a lot of things."\n

Joe Biden: "What we did federally, we said, you remember, George, it was all about the same time for the same crime."\n
Joe Biden: "What I had done as the Chairman of the Judiciary Committee, I took the 10 Circuit Courts of Appeals, took some really brilliant lawyers working for me in Judiciary, we did a study and we determined what happens if, for the first, second, third offense for any crime in the criminal justice system at the federal level, if you’re a Black man and it’s the first time you’ve committed robbery, how long would you go to jail?"\n

Joe Biden: "We should decriminalize marijuana, wipe out the record so you can actually say honesty, “You ever been arrested for murder for anything?” You can say no, because we’re going to pass a law saying there is no background that you have to reveal relative to the use of marijuana."\n
Joe Biden: "And so there’s a lot of things."\n
Joe Biden: "But in addition to that, we’ve got to change the system."\n
Joe Biden: "I joined with a group of people in the House to provide for changing the system from punishment to rehabilitation."\n
Joe Biden: "Along with a guy named Marlon Specter, who you may remember, I wrote the Second Chance Act."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "In the meantime, an awful lot of people were jailed for minor drug crimes after the Crime Bill."\n
Joe Biden: "Right."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "Was it a mistake to support it?"\n
Joe Biden: "Yes, it was."\n
Joe Biden: "But here’s where the mistake."\n
Joe Biden: "The mistake came in terms of what the states did locally."\n
Joe Biden: "What we did federally, we said, you remember, George, it was all about the same time for the same crime."\n
Joe Biden: "What I had done as the Chairman of the Judiciary Committee, I took the 10 Circuit Courts of Appeals, took some really brilliant lawyers working for me in Judiciary, we did a study and we determined what happens if, for the first, second, third offense for any crime in the criminal justice system at the federal level, if you’re a Black man and it’s the first time you’ve committed robbery, how long would you go to jail?"\n
Joe Biden: "On average?"\n
Joe Biden: "If you’re White man, how long?"\n
 n050116b07p1617 40000 5 For me, this is "support," because Joe is showing that he agrees with the first sentence. support 50000 5 its very clear that is supporting argument. support 80000 3 Biden agrees with George support
Joe Biden: "The mistake came in terms of what the states did locally."\n
Joe Biden: "What we did federally, we said, you remember, George, it was all about the same time for the same crime."\n
Joe Biden: "What I had done as the Chairman of the Judiciary Committee, I took the 10 Circuit Courts of Appeals, took some really brilliant lawyers working for me in Judiciary, we did a study and we determined what happens if, for the first, second, third offense for any crime in the criminal justice system at the federal level, if you’re a Black man and it’s the first time you’ve committed robbery, how long would you go to jail?"\n
Joe Biden: "On average?"\n
Joe Biden: "If you’re White man, how long?"\n
Joe Biden: "The Black man would go to jail on average 13 years."\n
Joe Biden: "White man, two years."\n
Joe Biden: "I’d go down the list of every single crime."\n
Joe Biden: "So we set up a sentencing commission."\n
Joe Biden: "We didn’t set the time."\n
Joe Biden: "Every single solitary maximum was reduced in there."\n
Joe Biden: "But what happened was it became the same time for the same crime."\n
Joe Biden: "So it said, “You have to serve between one and three years.” And it ended up becoming much lower, Black folks went to jail a lot less than they would have before."\n
Joe Biden: "But it was a mistake."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "Let me ask another follow-up on the Crime bill."\n

Joe Biden: "What I had done as the Chairman of the Judiciary Committee, I took the 10 Circuit Courts of Appeals, took some really brilliant lawyers working for me in Judiciary, we did a study and we determined what happens if, for the first, second, third offense for any crime in the criminal justice system at the federal level, if you’re a Black man and it’s the first time you’ve committed robbery, how long would you go to jail?"\n
Joe Biden: "On average?"\n
Joe Biden: "If you’re White man, how long?"\n
Joe Biden: "The Black man would go to jail on average 13 years."\n
Joe Biden: "White man, two years."\n
Joe Biden: "I’d go down the list of every single crime."\n
Joe Biden: "So we set up a sentencing commission."\n
Joe Biden: "We didn’t set the time."\n
Joe Biden: "Every single solitary maximum was reduced in there."\n
Joe Biden: "But what happened was it became the same time for the same crime."\n
Joe Biden: "So it said, “You have to serve between one and three years.” And it ended up becoming much lower, Black folks went to jail a lot less than they would have before."\n
Joe Biden: "But it was a mistake."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "Let me ask another follow-up on the Crime bill."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "It also funded 100,000 police back in 1994."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "You’ve often said that more cops clearly mean less crime."\n

Joe Biden: "We didn’t set the time."\n
Joe Biden: "Every single solitary maximum was reduced in there."\n
Joe Biden: "But what happened was it became the same time for the same crime."\n
Joe Biden: "So it said, “You have to serve between one and three years.” And it ended up becoming much lower, Black folks went to jail a lot less than they would have before."\n
Joe Biden: "But it was a mistake."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "Let me ask another follow-up on the Crime bill."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "It also funded 100,000 police back in 1994."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "You’ve often said that more cops clearly mean less crime."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "Do you still believe that?"\n
Joe Biden: "Yes, if in fact they’re involved in community policing, not jump squads."\n
Joe Biden: "For example, when we had community policing, from the mid-’90s on until till Bush got elected, what happened?"\n
Joe Biden: "Violent crime actually went down precipitous."\n
Joe Biden: "Remember the significant rise in violent crime that was occurring in the late ’80s into the ’90s."\n
Joe Biden: "It went down and fewer African Americans were arrested because you had the requirement."\n
Joe Biden: "The cops didn’t like it."\n

George Stephanopoulos: "Do you still believe that?"\n
Joe Biden: "Yes, if in fact they’re involved in community policing, not jump squads."\n

 n050135b07p3640 40000 5 not_argumentative neither 50000 5 not_argumentative neither 80000 4 not_argumentative neither
Joe Biden: "So it said, “You have to serve between one and three years.” And it ended up becoming much lower, Black folks went to jail a lot less than they would have before."\n
Joe Biden: "But it was a mistake."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "Let me ask another follow-up on the Crime bill."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "It also funded 100,000 police back in 1994."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "You’ve often said that more cops clearly mean less crime."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "Do you still believe that?"\n
Joe Biden: "Yes, if in fact they’re involved in community policing, not jump squads."\n
Joe Biden: "For example, when we had community policing, from the mid-’90s on until till Bush got elected, what happened?"\n
Joe Biden: "Violent crime actually went down precipitous."\n
Joe Biden: "Remember the significant rise in violent crime that was occurring in the late ’80s into the ’90s."\n
Joe Biden: "It went down and fewer African Americans were arrested because you had the requirement."\n
Joe Biden: "The cops didn’t like it."\n
Joe Biden: "They didn’t like the community policing, because you had to have two people in the vehicle, they had to get out of their cars, they had to introduce themselves to who own the local liquor store, who owned the local grocery store, who was the woman on the corner."\n
Joe Biden: "And what they would do, George, they’d actually go and give people their phone numbers."\n
Joe Biden: "A cop would give the phone number."\n

Joe Biden: "So it said, “You have to serve between one and three years.” And it ended up becoming much lower, Black folks went to jail a lot less than they would have before."\n
Joe Biden: "But it was a mistake."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "Let me ask another follow-up on the Crime bill."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "It also funded 100,000 police back in 1994."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "You’ve often said that more cops clearly mean less crime."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "Do you still believe that?"\n
Joe Biden: "Yes, if in fact they’re involved in community policing, not jump squads."\n
Joe Biden: "For example, when we had community policing, from the mid-’90s on until till Bush got elected, what happened?"\n
Joe Biden: "Violent crime actually went down precipitous."\n
Joe Biden: "Remember the significant rise in violent crime that was occurring in the late ’80s into the ’90s."\n
Joe Biden: "It went down and fewer African Americans were arrested because you had the requirement."\n
Joe Biden: "The cops didn’t like it."\n

Joe Biden: "And what they would do, George, they’d actually go and give people their phone numbers."\n

George Stephanopoulos: "Let me ask another follow-up on the Crime bill."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "It also funded 100,000 police back in 1994."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "You’ve often said that more cops clearly mean less crime."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "Do you still believe that?"\n
Joe Biden: "Yes, if in fact they’re involved in community policing, not jump squads."\n
Joe Biden: "For example, when we had community policing, from the mid-’90s on until till Bush got elected, what happened?"\n
Joe Biden: "Violent crime actually went down precipitous."\n
Joe Biden: "Remember the significant rise in violent crime that was occurring in the late ’80s into the ’90s."\n
Joe Biden: "It went down and fewer African Americans were arrested because you had the requirement."\n
Joe Biden: "The cops didn’t like it."\n
Joe Biden: "They didn’t like the community policing, because you had to have two people in the vehicle, they had to get out of their cars, they had to introduce themselves to who own the local liquor store, who owned the local grocery store, who was the woman on the corner."\n
Joe Biden: "And what they would do, George, they’d actually go and give people their phone numbers."\n
Joe Biden: "A cop would give the phone number."\n
Joe Biden: "So if Nelly Smith was on the second floor where drug deals took place and things happened below her apartment, she could call and say, “It’s Millie, and there’s something going on here.” And they’d never revealed it was her, because they’d know, if she knew that, in fact, they report, they’d never report the crime, she’d never report."\n
 n050139b07p3740 60000 3 not_related neither 50000 5 not_related neither 90000 5 incomplete neither
Joe Biden: "It went down and fewer African Americans were arrested because you had the requirement."\n
Joe Biden: "The cops didn’t like it."\n
Joe Biden: "They didn’t like the community policing, because you had to have two people in the vehicle, they had to get out of their cars, they had to introduce themselves to who own the local liquor store, who owned the local grocery store, who was the woman on the corner."\n
Joe Biden: "And what they would do, George, they’d actually go and give people their phone numbers."\n
Joe Biden: "A cop would give the phone number."\n
Joe Biden: "So if Nelly Smith was on the second floor where drug deals took place and things happened below her apartment, she could call and say, “It’s Millie, and there’s something going on here.” And they’d never revealed it was her, because they’d know, if she knew that, in fact, they report, they’d never report the crime, she’d never report."\n
Joe Biden: "So it actually started to come down."\n
Joe Biden: "And what happened?"\n
Joe Biden: "They eliminated the funding for community policing."\n
Joe Biden: "Community policing doesn’t mean more people coming in, in armored Humvees and swarming."\n
Joe Biden: "It turned out that by the time we got to the late ’90s and crime had come down so much, the mayors and everybody asked the question, “Where do you want me to spend the money?” They say, “Well, only 1% thought violent crime was a problem.” It was as high as 22%."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "Right now we have a systemic problem."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "How do you get the kind of policing, prevent the kind of policing [crosstalk 00:35:55]."\n
Joe Biden: "You have to change the way in which they [inaudible 00:35:55]."\n
Joe Biden: "One of the things I’m going to do, George, is what is set up a national study group made up of cops, social workers, as well as made up of the Black community and the Brown community to sit down in the White House and over the next year come up with significant reforms that need to take place within communities."\n

Joe Biden: "The cops didn’t like it."\n

Joe Biden: "And what they would do, George, they’d actually go and give people their phone numbers."\n

Joe Biden: "So if Nelly Smith was on the second floor where drug deals took place and things happened below her apartment, she could call and say, “It’s Millie, and there’s something going on here.” And they’d never revealed it was her, because they’d know, if she knew that, in fact, they report, they’d never report the crime, she’d never report."\n
Joe Biden: "So it actually started to come down."\n
Joe Biden: "And what happened?"\n

Joe Biden: "Community policing doesn’t mean more people coming in, in armored Humvees and swarming."\n
Joe Biden: "It turned out that by the time we got to the late ’90s and crime had come down so much, the mayors and everybody asked the question, “Where do you want me to spend the money?” They say, “Well, only 1% thought violent crime was a problem.” It was as high as 22%."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "Right now we have a systemic problem."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "How do you get the kind of policing, prevent the kind of policing [crosstalk 00:35:55]."\n
Joe Biden: "You have to change the way in which they [inaudible 00:35:55]."\n
Joe Biden: "One of the things I’m going to do, George, is what is set up a national study group made up of cops, social workers, as well as made up of the Black community and the Brown community to sit down in the White House and over the next year come up with significant reforms that need to take place within communities."\n
Joe Biden: "You have to bring them together."\n

Joe Biden: "So if Nelly Smith was on the second floor where drug deals took place and things happened below her apartment, she could call and say, “It’s Millie, and there’s something going on here.” And they’d never revealed it was her, because they’d know, if she knew that, in fact, they report, they’d never report the crime, she’d never report."\n
Joe Biden: "So it actually started to come down."\n
Joe Biden: "And what happened?"\n
Joe Biden: "They eliminated the funding for community policing."\n
Joe Biden: "Community policing doesn’t mean more people coming in, in armored Humvees and swarming."\n
Joe Biden: "It turned out that by the time we got to the late ’90s and crime had come down so much, the mayors and everybody asked the question, “Where do you want me to spend the money?” They say, “Well, only 1% thought violent crime was a problem.” It was as high as 22%."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "Right now we have a systemic problem."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "How do you get the kind of policing, prevent the kind of policing [crosstalk 00:35:55]."\n

Joe Biden: "One of the things I’m going to do, George, is what is set up a national study group made up of cops, social workers, as well as made up of the Black community and the Brown community to sit down in the White House and over the next year come up with significant reforms that need to take place within communities."\n
Joe Biden: "You have to bring them together."\n
Joe Biden: "One of the things I’ve observed is, the neighborhood I grew up, I grew up in Claymont, you either became a cop, a firefighter, or a priest."\n
Joe Biden: "I wasn’t qualified much to do any one of them, but here’s the deal, all kidding aside."\n
Joe Biden: "Most cops don’t like bad cops."\n
Audience Member 5: "Correct."\n

Audience Member 5: "Correct."\n
Joe Biden: "They don’t like it."\n
Audience Member 5: "That’s correct."\n
Joe Biden: "And so what happens is they get intimidated into not reporting."\n
Joe Biden: "So one of the things we do is there has to be transparency available."\n
Joe Biden: "We have to be able to go in at the federal level, be able to go in and check out whether or not there’s systematic problems within police departments."\n
Joe Biden: "If, in fact, a cop needs to be tried, it’s not the prosecutor in the community, in the district there."\n
Joe Biden: "You’ve got to go outside the community to get another prosecutor to come in to handle the crime."\n
Joe Biden: "There’s a lot of things we’ve learned, and it takes time but we can do this."\n
Joe Biden: "You can ban choke holds, but beyond that, you have to teach people how to de-escalate circumstances."\n

Joe Biden: "They don’t like it."\n
Audience Member 5: "That’s correct."\n
Joe Biden: "And so what happens is they get intimidated into not reporting."\n
Joe Biden: "So one of the things we do is there has to be transparency available."\n
Joe Biden: "We have to be able to go in at the federal level, be able to go in and check out whether or not there’s systematic problems within police departments."\n
Joe Biden: "If, in fact, a cop needs to be tried, it’s not the prosecutor in the community, in the district there."\n
Joe Biden: "You’ve got to go outside the community to get another prosecutor to come in to handle the crime."\n
Joe Biden: "There’s a lot of things we’ve learned, and it takes time but we can do this."\n
Joe Biden: "You can ban choke holds, but beyond that, you have to teach people how to de-escalate circumstances."\n
 n050162b07p6566 90000 5 not_related neither 50000 5 not_argumentative neither 60000 3 not_argumentative neither
Joe Biden: "So one of the things we do is there has to be transparency available."\n
Joe Biden: "We have to be able to go in at the federal level, be able to go in and check out whether or not there’s systematic problems within police departments."\n
Joe Biden: "If, in fact, a cop needs to be tried, it’s not the prosecutor in the community, in the district there."\n
Joe Biden: "You’ve got to go outside the community to get another prosecutor to come in to handle the crime."\n
Joe Biden: "There’s a lot of things we’ve learned, and it takes time but we can do this."\n
Joe Biden: "You can ban choke holds, but beyond that, you have to teach people how to de-escalate circumstances."\n
Joe Biden: "De-escalate."\n
Joe Biden: "So instead of anybody coming at you and the first thing you do is shoot to kill, you shoot them in the leg."\n
Joe Biden: "There’s ways you have to do more background checks in terms of whether or not the person coming in, passes a certain psychological test."\n
Joe Biden: "And the last thing I’ll say, and I’m sorry, but it’s really, I think, really, really important, is you have to be in a position where you are able to identify, identify the things that have to change."\n
Joe Biden: "And one of the things that has to change is so many cops get called into circumstances where somebody is mentally off."\n
Joe Biden: "Like what happened not long ago, that guy with the knife."\n
Joe Biden: "That’s why we have to provide within police departments psychologists and social workers to go out with the cops on those calls, some of those 911 calls to de-escalate the circumstance, to deal with talking them down."\n
Joe Biden: "But cops are kind of like school teachers now."\n
Joe Biden: "A school teacher has to know everything from how to handle hunger in a household as well as how to teach how to read."\n
 n050171b07p7178 80000 4 not_related neither 60000 3 these sentences are clearly supporting each other support 40000 5 not_argumentative neither
Joe Biden: "You’ve got to go outside the community to get another prosecutor to come in to handle the crime."\n
Joe Biden: "There’s a lot of things we’ve learned, and it takes time but we can do this."\n
Joe Biden: "You can ban choke holds, but beyond that, you have to teach people how to de-escalate circumstances."\n
Joe Biden: "De-escalate."\n
Joe Biden: "So instead of anybody coming at you and the first thing you do is shoot to kill, you shoot them in the leg."\n
Joe Biden: "There’s ways you have to do more background checks in terms of whether or not the person coming in, passes a certain psychological test."\n
Joe Biden: "And the last thing I’ll say, and I’m sorry, but it’s really, I think, really, really important, is you have to be in a position where you are able to identify, identify the things that have to change."\n
Joe Biden: "And one of the things that has to change is so many cops get called into circumstances where somebody is mentally off."\n
Joe Biden: "Like what happened not long ago, that guy with the knife."\n
Joe Biden: "That’s why we have to provide within police departments psychologists and social workers to go out with the cops on those calls, some of those 911 calls to de-escalate the circumstance, to deal with talking them down."\n
Joe Biden: "But cops are kind of like school teachers now."\n
Joe Biden: "A school teacher has to know everything from how to handle hunger in a household as well as how to teach how to read."\n
Joe Biden: "Well, cops or don’t have that breadth, and there’s a lot of things we can do."\n
Joe Biden: "We shouldn’t be defunding cops."\n
Joe Biden: "We should be mandating the things that we should be doing within police departments and make sure there’s total transparency."\n
 n050174b07p6971 40000 5 Both sentences show an attack. attack 50000 5 not_argumentative neither 80000 4 Biden's statement is about de-escalation support
Joe Biden: "There’s a lot of things we’ve learned, and it takes time but we can do this."\n
Joe Biden: "You can ban choke holds, but beyond that, you have to teach people how to de-escalate circumstances."\n
Joe Biden: "De-escalate."\n
Joe Biden: "So instead of anybody coming at you and the first thing you do is shoot to kill, you shoot them in the leg."\n
Joe Biden: "There’s ways you have to do more background checks in terms of whether or not the person coming in, passes a certain psychological test."\n
Joe Biden: "And the last thing I’ll say, and I’m sorry, but it’s really, I think, really, really important, is you have to be in a position where you are able to identify, identify the things that have to change."\n
Joe Biden: "And one of the things that has to change is so many cops get called into circumstances where somebody is mentally off."\n
Joe Biden: "Like what happened not long ago, that guy with the knife."\n
Joe Biden: "That’s why we have to provide within police departments psychologists and social workers to go out with the cops on those calls, some of those 911 calls to de-escalate the circumstance, to deal with talking them down."\n
Joe Biden: "But cops are kind of like school teachers now."\n
Joe Biden: "A school teacher has to know everything from how to handle hunger in a household as well as how to teach how to read."\n
Joe Biden: "Well, cops or don’t have that breadth, and there’s a lot of things we can do."\n
Joe Biden: "We shouldn’t be defunding cops."\n
Joe Biden: "We should be mandating the things that we should be doing within police departments and make sure there’s total transparency."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "Got to take another quick break."\n
 n050175b07p7576 80000 3 Biden's statement is about the needed policy to prevent racism support 60000 3 not_related neither 50000 5 not_argumentative neither
Joe Biden: "De-escalate."\n
Joe Biden: "So instead of anybody coming at you and the first thing you do is shoot to kill, you shoot them in the leg."\n
Joe Biden: "There’s ways you have to do more background checks in terms of whether or not the person coming in, passes a certain psychological test."\n
Joe Biden: "And the last thing I’ll say, and I’m sorry, but it’s really, I think, really, really important, is you have to be in a position where you are able to identify, identify the things that have to change."\n
Joe Biden: "And one of the things that has to change is so many cops get called into circumstances where somebody is mentally off."\n
Joe Biden: "Like what happened not long ago, that guy with the knife."\n
Joe Biden: "That’s why we have to provide within police departments psychologists and social workers to go out with the cops on those calls, some of those 911 calls to de-escalate the circumstance, to deal with talking them down."\n
Joe Biden: "But cops are kind of like school teachers now."\n
Joe Biden: "A school teacher has to know everything from how to handle hunger in a household as well as how to teach how to read."\n
Joe Biden: "Well, cops or don’t have that breadth, and there’s a lot of things we can do."\n
Joe Biden: "We shouldn’t be defunding cops."\n
Joe Biden: "We should be mandating the things that we should be doing within police departments and make sure there’s total transparency."\n

George Stephanopoulos: "We’ll be right back."\n
Joe Biden: "I don’t know the answer to your question."\n

Joe Biden: "And one of the things that has to change is so many cops get called into circumstances where somebody is mentally off."\n
Joe Biden: "Like what happened not long ago, that guy with the knife."\n
Joe Biden: "That’s why we have to provide within police departments psychologists and social workers to go out with the cops on those calls, some of those 911 calls to de-escalate the circumstance, to deal with talking them down."\n
Joe Biden: "But cops are kind of like school teachers now."\n

Joe Biden: "Hey, Nathan."\n
Audience Member 6: "Our country’s first Supreme Court gave its first ruling is just two blocks from here from 1791 to 1800, and it’s become more polarized since then."\n
Audience Member 6: "Merrick Garland didn’t get a hearing for all of 2016 and Amy Coney Barrett is being pushed through at the last minute, even though millions have already voted."\n
Audience Member 6: "So what do you think about ideas from people like Pete Buttigieg and others to put in place safeguards that will help ensure more long-term balance and stability?"\n
Audience Member 6: "And what do you say to LGBTQ Americans and others who are very worried right now about erosions of their rights and our democracy as a whole?"\n
Joe Biden: "Well, let me start at the last point and work my way back."\n
Joe Biden: "I think there’s great reason to be concerned."\n
Joe Biden: "I was on the road most of the time during these hearings so I didn’t hear many of them."\n
Joe Biden: "I just got the recaps when I’d get in late at night."\n

Joe Biden: "Hey, Nathan."\n
Audience Member 6: "Our country’s first Supreme Court gave its first ruling is just two blocks from here from 1791 to 1800, and it’s become more polarized since then."\n
Audience Member 6: "Merrick Garland didn’t get a hearing for all of 2016 and Amy Coney Barrett is being pushed through at the last minute, even though millions have already voted."\n
Audience Member 6: "So what do you think about ideas from people like Pete Buttigieg and others to put in place safeguards that will help ensure more long-term balance and stability?"\n
Audience Member 6: "And what do you say to LGBTQ Americans and others who are very worried right now about erosions of their rights and our democracy as a whole?"\n
Joe Biden: "Well, let me start at the last point and work my way back."\n
Joe Biden: "I think there’s great reason to be concerned."\n
Joe Biden: "I was on the road most of the time during these hearings so I didn’t hear many of them."\n
Joe Biden: "I just got the recaps when I’d get in late at night."\n
Joe Biden: "I’m been going around the country, Florida, anyway, but my reading online what the judge said was she didn’t answer very many questions at all."\n
Joe Biden: "And I don’t even think she is laid out much of a judicial philosophy in terms of the basis upon which she thinks are there unenumerated rights in the Constitution, nonetheless."\n
Joe Biden: "So, number one."\n
Joe Biden: "So I think there’s great reason to be concerned for the LGBT community, something I fought very hard for, for a long time to make sure there’s equality across the board."\n
Joe Biden: "Number two, I think that also healthcare overall is very much in jeopardy as a consequence of the President’s going to go directly after this election directly to the Supreme Court within a month to try to get Obamacare wiped out after 10 million people have already lost her insurance from their employer and wants to take 20 million people out of the system as well, plus 100 million people with pre-existing conditions."\n
Joe Biden: "So there’s a lot at stake."\n

Audience Member 6: "Our country’s first Supreme Court gave its first ruling is just two blocks from here from 1791 to 1800, and it’s become more polarized since then."\n

Audience Member 6: "And what do you say to LGBTQ Americans and others who are very worried right now about erosions of their rights and our democracy as a whole?"\n
Joe Biden: "Well, let me start at the last point and work my way back."\n
Joe Biden: "I think there’s great reason to be concerned."\n
Joe Biden: "I was on the road most of the time during these hearings so I didn’t hear many of them."\n
Joe Biden: "I just got the recaps when I’d get in late at night."\n
Joe Biden: "I’m been going around the country, Florida, anyway, but my reading online what the judge said was she didn’t answer very many questions at all."\n
Joe Biden: "And I don’t even think she is laid out much of a judicial philosophy in terms of the basis upon which she thinks are there unenumerated rights in the Constitution, nonetheless."\n
Joe Biden: "So, number one."\n
Joe Biden: "So I think there’s great reason to be concerned for the LGBT community, something I fought very hard for, for a long time to make sure there’s equality across the board."\n
Joe Biden: "Number two, I think that also healthcare overall is very much in jeopardy as a consequence of the President’s going to go directly after this election directly to the Supreme Court within a month to try to get Obamacare wiped out after 10 million people have already lost her insurance from their employer and wants to take 20 million people out of the system as well, plus 100 million people with pre-existing conditions."\n
Joe Biden: "So there’s a lot at stake."\n
Joe Biden: "I don’t think it’s appropriate."\n

Joe Biden: "Well, let me start at the last point and work my way back."\n
Joe Biden: "I think there’s great reason to be concerned."\n
Joe Biden: "I was on the road most of the time during these hearings so I didn’t hear many of them."\n
Joe Biden: "I just got the recaps when I’d get in late at night."\n
Joe Biden: "I’m been going around the country, Florida, anyway, but my reading online what the judge said was she didn’t answer very many questions at all."\n
Joe Biden: "And I don’t even think she is laid out much of a judicial philosophy in terms of the basis upon which she thinks are there unenumerated rights in the Constitution, nonetheless."\n
Joe Biden: "So, number one."\n
Joe Biden: "So I think there’s great reason to be concerned for the LGBT community, something I fought very hard for, for a long time to make sure there’s equality across the board."\n
Joe Biden: "Number two, I think that also healthcare overall is very much in jeopardy as a consequence of the President’s going to go directly after this election directly to the Supreme Court within a month to try to get Obamacare wiped out after 10 million people have already lost her insurance from their employer and wants to take 20 million people out of the system as well, plus 100 million people with pre-existing conditions."\n
Joe Biden: "So there’s a lot at stake."\n
Joe Biden: "I don’t think it’s appropriate."\n
Joe Biden: "I think the Constitution implies, there’s no provision in the Constitution, my problem is I made a mistake of teaching constitutional law for 21 years, and the separation of powers, the Constitution implies that their way the people have a right to determine who’s going to be on the court is how they vote for their Senators and their President."\n

Joe Biden: "Well, let me start at the last point and work my way back."\n
Joe Biden: "I think there’s great reason to be concerned."\n
Joe Biden: "I was on the road most of the time during these hearings so I didn’t hear many of them."\n
Joe Biden: "I just got the recaps when I’d get in late at night."\n
Joe Biden: "I’m been going around the country, Florida, anyway, but my reading online what the judge said was she didn’t answer very many questions at all."\n
Joe Biden: "And I don’t even think she is laid out much of a judicial philosophy in terms of the basis upon which she thinks are there unenumerated rights in the Constitution, nonetheless."\n
Joe Biden: "So, number one."\n
Joe Biden: "So I think there’s great reason to be concerned for the LGBT community, something I fought very hard for, for a long time to make sure there’s equality across the board."\n
Joe Biden: "Number two, I think that also healthcare overall is very much in jeopardy as a consequence of the President’s going to go directly after this election directly to the Supreme Court within a month to try to get Obamacare wiped out after 10 million people have already lost her insurance from their employer and wants to take 20 million people out of the system as well, plus 100 million people with pre-existing conditions."\n
Joe Biden: "So there’s a lot at stake."\n
Joe Biden: "I don’t think it’s appropriate."\n
Joe Biden: "I think the Constitution implies, there’s no provision in the Constitution, my problem is I made a mistake of teaching constitutional law for 21 years, and the separation of powers, the Constitution implies that their way the people have a right to determine who’s going to be on the court is how they vote for their Senators and their President."\n
Joe Biden: "We seek the advice and consent of the Senate."\n
Joe Biden: "And the President-"\n
George Stephanopoulos: "The President is President for all four years, isn’t he?"\n

Joe Biden: "Well, let me start at the last point and work my way back."\n
Joe Biden: "I think there’s great reason to be concerned."\n

Joe Biden: "I’m been going around the country, Florida, anyway, but my reading online what the judge said was she didn’t answer very many questions at all."\n
Joe Biden: "And I don’t even think she is laid out much of a judicial philosophy in terms of the basis upon which she thinks are there unenumerated rights in the Constitution, nonetheless."\n
Joe Biden: "So, number one."\n
Joe Biden: "So I think there’s great reason to be concerned for the LGBT community, something I fought very hard for, for a long time to make sure there’s equality across the board."\n
Joe Biden: "Number two, I think that also healthcare overall is very much in jeopardy as a consequence of the President’s going to go directly after this election directly to the Supreme Court within a month to try to get Obamacare wiped out after 10 million people have already lost her insurance from their employer and wants to take 20 million people out of the system as well, plus 100 million people with pre-existing conditions."\n
Joe Biden: "So there’s a lot at stake."\n
Joe Biden: "I don’t think it’s appropriate."\n
Joe Biden: "I think the Constitution implies, there’s no provision in the Constitution, my problem is I made a mistake of teaching constitutional law for 21 years, and the separation of powers, the Constitution implies that their way the people have a right to determine who’s going to be on the court is how they vote for their Senators and their President."\n
Joe Biden: "We seek the advice and consent of the Senate."\n
Joe Biden: "And the President-"\n
George Stephanopoulos: "The President is President for all four years, isn’t he?"\n

Joe Biden: "I was on the road most of the time during these hearings so I didn’t hear many of them."\n

Joe Biden: "I’m been going around the country, Florida, anyway, but my reading online what the judge said was she didn’t answer very many questions at all."\n
Joe Biden: "And I don’t even think she is laid out much of a judicial philosophy in terms of the basis upon which she thinks are there unenumerated rights in the Constitution, nonetheless."\n
Joe Biden: "So, number one."\n
Joe Biden: "So I think there’s great reason to be concerned for the LGBT community, something I fought very hard for, for a long time to make sure there’s equality across the board."\n
Joe Biden: "Number two, I think that also healthcare overall is very much in jeopardy as a consequence of the President’s going to go directly after this election directly to the Supreme Court within a month to try to get Obamacare wiped out after 10 million people have already lost her insurance from their employer and wants to take 20 million people out of the system as well, plus 100 million people with pre-existing conditions."\n
Joe Biden: "So there’s a lot at stake."\n
Joe Biden: "I don’t think it’s appropriate."\n
Joe Biden: "I think the Constitution implies, there’s no provision in the Constitution, my problem is I made a mistake of teaching constitutional law for 21 years, and the separation of powers, the Constitution implies that their way the people have a right to determine who’s going to be on the court is how they vote for their Senators and their President."\n
Joe Biden: "We seek the advice and consent of the Senate."\n
Joe Biden: "And the President-"\n
George Stephanopoulos: "The President is President for all four years, isn’t he?"\n
Joe Biden: "He is."\n
Joe Biden: "But once an election begins, by implication, it is inconsistent with the constitutional principles, in my view."\n

Joe Biden: "Instead of on, is it appropriate what is going on now?"\n
Joe Biden: "And it should stay."\n
Joe Biden: "This is the thing that the President loves to do, always take our eye off the ball what’s at stake."\n
Joe Biden: "One of the things Pete has suggested is, and there’s a number of constitutional scholars have suggested as well, that there are at least four or five options that are available to determine whether or not you can change the way in which the court lifetime appointment takes place consistent arguably with the Constitution."\n
Joe Biden: "I have not been a fan of court packing because then it just generates what will happen."\n
Joe Biden: "Whoever wins, it just keeps moving in a way that is inconsistent with what is going to be manageable."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "So you’re still not a fan?"\n
Joe Biden: "Well, I’m not a fan."\n
Joe Biden: "It depends on how this turns out."\n
Joe Biden: "Not how he wins, but how it’s handled, how it’s handled."\n

Joe Biden: "And I work with a number of Democrats and Republicans."\n
Joe Biden: "And we had a bill that was about $9 billion that made significant increases in research and development on cancer alternatives, NIH and particularly specific cancer initiatives."\n

Joe Biden: "I don’t hold any exact number."\n
Joe Biden: "And we had fewer than 40 in the Senate, but after he was elected, I got those people together as vice president and we sat down and we worked it out and we ended up getting a pass 396 votes in the house and 94 votes in the Senate."\n

Joe Biden: "Okay?"\n
Joe Biden: "And it was called the Cancer Moonshot."\n
Joe Biden: "And I work with a number of Democrats and Republicans."\n
Joe Biden: "And we had a bill that was about $9 billion that made significant increases in research and development on cancer alternatives, NIH and particularly specific cancer initiatives."\n
Joe Biden: "And we only had at the time I think it was 111 or 114, whatever it was, votes in the house."\n
Joe Biden: "I don’t hold any exact number."\n
Joe Biden: "And we had fewer than 40 in the Senate, but after he was elected, I got those people together as vice president and we sat down and we worked it out and we ended up getting a pass 396 votes in the house and 94 votes in the Senate."\n

George Stephanopoulos: "What would a Biden Justice Department do with that evidence?"\n
Joe Biden: "What the Biden Justice Department will do is let the Department of Justice be the Department of Justice."\n

Joe Biden: "And we only had at the time I think it was 111 or 114, whatever it was, votes in the house."\n
Joe Biden: "I don’t hold any exact number."\n
Joe Biden: "And we had fewer than 40 in the Senate, but after he was elected, I got those people together as vice president and we sat down and we worked it out and we ended up getting a pass 396 votes in the house and 94 votes in the Senate."\n

George Stephanopoulos: "What would a Biden Justice Department do with that evidence?"\n
Joe Biden: "What the Biden Justice Department will do is let the Department of Justice be the Department of Justice."\n
Joe Biden: "Let them make the judgments of who should be prosecuted."\n
Joe Biden: "They’re not my lawyers."\n
Joe Biden: "They’re not my personal lawyer."\n
George Stephanopoulos: "So, you’re not going to rule it in or rule it out?"\n
Joe Biden: "I’m not going to rule in or out."\n
Joe Biden: "Well, I’m going to hire really first rate prosecutors and people who understand the law like Democrat and Republican administrations have had, and let them make the judgements, but turning this into a vehicle for your, as if it’s your own law firm, you don’t own that justice department."\n
Joe Biden: "You pick the best people you can and you hope that what they’re going to do is they’re going to enforce the law as they see it."\n
Joe Biden: "But can you remember any Republican president going out there or former Democratic president go find that guy and prosecute him?"\n
